facts.text: A Division Bench of 2-Judges of this Court referred the instant appeals for disposal by a larger bench by its referral order dated 27th October, 2004

anchor.surface_text: a Division Bench of 2-Judges of this Court referred the instant appeals for disposal by a larger bench by its referral order dated 27th October, 2004, hence, this appeal is before us.

facts.text: One Hirday Ram was the owner of the suit property

anchor.surface_text: One Hirday Ram was the owner of the suit property. He had three wives, namely, Kubja, Pari and Uttamdassi.

facts.text: Hirday Ram had three wives, namely, Kubja, Pari and Uttamdassi

anchor.surface_text: He had three wives, namely, Kubja, Pari and Uttamdassi. Kubja had pre- deceased Hirday Ram leaving behind a daughter named Tikami.

facts.text: Kubja had pre-deceased Hirday Ram leaving behind a daughter named Tikami

anchor.surface_text: Kubja had pre- deceased Hirday Ram leaving behind a daughter named Tikami. During his life time, Hirday Ram made a Will dated 1.10.1938

facts.text: Hirday Ram made a Will dated 1.10.1938

anchor.surface_text: During his life time, Hirday Ram made a Will dated 1.10.1938 whereby he bequeathed a part of his property to his daughter Tikami

facts.text: By the Will, Hirday Ram bequeathed a part of his property to his daughter Tikami and the remaining property was given to his two other wives for their maintenance with the condition that they would not have the power to alienate the same

anchor.surface_text: whereby he bequeathed a part of his property to his daughter Tikami and the remaining property was given to his two other wives, named above, for their maintenance with the condition that they would not have the power to alienate the same in any manner.

facts.text: As per the Will, after the death of the above two wives of Hirday Ram, the property was to revert back to his daughter Tikami as absolute owner

anchor.surface_text: As per the Will, after the death of the above two wives of Hirday Ram, the property was to revert back to his daughter Tikami as absolute owner.

facts.text: After the death of Hirday Ram and his second wife Pari in 1939, the property in question came to be vested with the third wife, Uttamdassi as per the terms of the Will

anchor.surface_text: After the death of Hirday Ram and his second wife Pari in 1939, the property in question came to be vested with the third wife, Uttamdassi as per the terms of the Will.

facts.text: After the coming into force of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956, Uttamdassi claiming to be the absolute owner sold a part of the property to one Sandup on 28.11.1958

anchor.surface_text: After the coming into force of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956, Uttamdassi claiming to be the absolute owner sold a part of the property to one Sandup on 28.11.1958 predecessor-in-interest of respondent Nos.1 and 2 herein.

facts.text: Sandup is predecessor-in-interest of respondent Nos.1 and 2

anchor.surface_text: predecessor-in-interest of respondent Nos.1 and 2 herein. The said Sandup mortgaged back the property to Uttamdassi who on 2.12.1958

facts.text: The said Sandup mortgaged back the property to Uttamdassi

anchor.surface_text: The said Sandup mortgaged back the property to Uttamdassi who on 2.12.1958 made a gift of another property in favour of respondent No.3 herein

facts.text: Uttamdassi made a gift of another property in favour of respondent No.3 on 2.12.1958 who in turn sold it to respondent No.4

anchor.surface_text: who on 2.12.1958 made a gift of another property in favour of respondent No.3 herein who in turn sold to it respondent No.4.

facts.text: The appellant herein is a daughter of Tikami and granddaughter of Hirday Ram

anchor.surface_text: The appellant herein is a daughter of Tikami and granddaughter of Hirday Ram filed a suit challenging the alienation made by Uttamdassi

facts.text: Appellant filed a suit challenging the alienation made by Uttamdassi seeking a decree for declaration that the alienation would not affect her reversionary rights

anchor.surface_text: filed a suit challenging the alienation made by Uttamdassi seeking a decree for declaration that the alienation made by Uttamdassi would not affect her reversionary rights.

facts.text: The suit was decreed by the trial court on 12.7.1961

anchor.surface_text: The suit was decreed by the trial court on 12.7.1961. Appeal filed by Uttamdassi was dismissed on 25.1.1963.

facts.text: Appeal filed by Uttamdassi was dismissed on 25.1.1963. Thus the said declaratory decree became final

anchor.surface_text: Appeal filed by Uttamdassi was dismissed on 25.1.1963. Thus the said declaratory decree became final as it was not put to challenge in further appeal in the High Court.

facts.text: On 24.5.1975 Uttamdassi gifted the property sold by her to Sandup in 1958 in favour of respondent No.5

anchor.surface_text: On 24.5.1975 Uttamdassi gifted the property sold by her to Sandup in 1958 in favour of respondent No.5.

facts.text: Appellant filed a suit challenging the said alienation; trial court dismissed the suit but First Appellate Court accepted the appeal and held the gift void ab initio

anchor.surface_text: The appellant herein again filed a suit challenging the said alienation also and seeking a declaration that the said alienation made by Uttamdassi would not affect her reversionary rights.

facts.text: This decree also became final as it was not put to any further challenge

anchor.surface_text: This decree also became absolute as the same was not put to any further challenge.

facts.text: Uttamdassi had gifted a part of the property in favour of respondent No.5 by way of a Will on 27.12.1986

anchor.surface_text: It is relevant to mention herein that Uttamdassi had gifted a part of the property in favour of respondent No.5 by way of a Will on 27.12.1986.

facts.text: Uttamdassi died on 1.1.1987

anchor.surface_text: She died on 1.1.1987.

facts.text: After the death of Uttamdassi, appellant brought a suit for possession of the suit property being the nearest reversioner

anchor.surface_text: After the death of Uttamdassi, appellant the granddaughter of the original owner Hirday Ram brought a suit for possession of the suit property

facts.text: The trial court dismissed the suit on 22.8.1989

anchor.surface_text: The trial court dismissed the suit on 22.8.1989.

facts.text: Relying upon V.Tulasamma vs. V.Sesha Reddy 1977 3 SCC 99, trial court held Uttamdassi became absolute owner under Section 14(1) of Hindu Succession Act, 1956

anchor.surface_text: Relying upon a judgment of this Court in the case of V.Tulasamma vs. V.Sesha Reddy 1977 3 SCC 99 holding, inter alia, that though the suit property was given to the wives of Hirday Ram as limited owners but in view of Section 14(1) of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 Uttamdassi became the absolute owner

facts.text: Appeal filed by the appellant was dismissed on 30.9.1991 by the First Appellate Court

facts.text: The regular second appeal was dismissed by the impugned judgment of the High Court

facts.text: High Court held that earlier declaratory decrees would not operate as res judicata because based on interpretation of Section 14 superseded by V.Tulasamma case

anchor.surface_text: holding inter alia that interpretation of Section 14 of the Hindu Succession Act, 1956 was a pure question of law and the earlier decrees obtained on the interpretation of law in the case of Mst. facts.text: The Supreme Court holds that the declaratory decrees obtained by the appellant being contrary to the judgment in V.Tulasammas case would not be of any assistance to obtain possession

anchor.surface_text: In the instant case, in our opinion, the High Court rightly held that the declaratory decrees obtained by the appellant being contrary to the judgment in Tulasammas case supra would not be of any assistance to the appellant to obtain the possession of the suit property.
